title: Bernard Verdcourt
text:
Bernard Verdcourt (20 January 1925 – 25 October 2011) was a <a href="biologist">biologist</a> and <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomist</a>, most widely known as a <a href="Botany">botanist</a> and latterly an honorary research fellow at the <a href="Royal%20Botanic%20Gardens%2C%20Kew">Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew</a> in London. Prior to coming to Kew in 1964, he was associated with the East African Herbarium for 15 years. Although his best-known work probably consists of his many studies of the East African <a href="flora">flora</a>, he has also made extensive contributions relating to African terrestrial <a href="Mollusca">mollusks</a> and to <a href="entomology">entomology</a>. Dr. Verdcourt received the Linnean Medal for botany from the <a href="Linnean%20Society%20of%20London">Linnean Society of London</a> in 2000. His list of publications includes more than 1,000 <a href="Scientific%20literature">scientific works</a>. 
In 2012, botanists H.Ohashi & K.Ohashi published "<a href="Verdesmum">Verdesmum</a>" is a <a href="monotypic%20genus">monotypic genus</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s from Malasia belonging to the family <a href="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>, it was named in Bernard Verdcourt's honour.
